stream_context.summary: Kaze primarily worked on a quick-draw duel minigame against the character Boshi. The stream focused on iterating the minigame's design, moving from a simple HUD to a cinematic cutscene, tweaking animations, and solving the complex technical problem of attaching a gun model to Mario's hand on the N64 engine. He also briefly tested the project on N64 hardware and discussed his strategies for dealing with potential Nintendo copyright takedowns.

development_findings.summary: To solve the problem of attaching a gun to Mario's hand, Kaze devised a creative and performant solution: rendering a second, invisible Mario model that shares the same animation data, with only the gun attached to its hand being visible.
development_findings.quote: I can see the vision now of copying Mario's rig and attaching the gun to just his hand and then rendering an invisible Mario with only the hand visible where the hand is the gun.

development_findings.summary: Kaze pivoted the design of the Boshi duel countdown from a simple HUD element to a full-fledged, cinematic cutscene after finding the programming for a dynamic HUD too cumbersome and the visual result unsatisfying.
development_findings.quote: We'll just make a cutscene fuck it this is painful to do without a cutscene.

development_findings.summary: Kaze tested the game on original N64 hardware, confirming that Course 5 runs at 40 FPS pre-optimization, while the overworld has a known crashing issue that needs to be fixed.
development_findings.quote: 40 FPS before we even optimized it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze stated the project is in its final fifth of development, with only three levels left to complete. He gives a tentative release window of sometime before 2026.
development_findings.quote: Do you guys actually realize how crazy it is how close we're done to being done like only three levels are missing... it's the last fifth of the game... I think release before 2026 maybe.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is concerned about the release timing, noting that launching a ROM hack at the same time as a major official Nintendo game is a surefire way to get it taken down immediately.
During the stream, Kaze iterated on Boshi's egg-juggling animation, initially hardcoding values and then using math to create a smoother, more realistic deceleration based on chat feedback.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a detailed history with Nintendo copyright takedowns, having had 70 videos removed. He anticipates the trailer for this game will also be taken down and plans to preemptively create a copyright-free version to release immediately after, which will also advertise the Kickstarter for his next original game.
context_findings.quote: A lot of people tell me that they're worried that this game is going to get taken down by Nintendo but I never understood what they think that would look like... They will absolutely take it down and I will have to release a copyright free version that is gonna happen and you know it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a firm stance against making content exclusive to his Patreon, indicating a principle of not wanting to bait people into paying for his fan-game work.
context_findings.quote: I'm not making any Patreon exclusives. I don't want people to even think I'm trying to bait people into my Patreon.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong dislike for low-effort or 'disgusting' humor like fart jokes, revealing a core principle about the kind of tone and quality he wants in his creative work.
context_findings.quote: I want you to think about what you just said. Think about if that's how you want to live your life. I don't know. This does not work for elimination. All that humor was so disgusting. I didn't even like it as a kid.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a critical view of RPG game mechanics, categorizing them into three archetypes (easy, grindy, or math problems), none of which he finds appealing.
context_findings.quote: There's two options for RPGs... One, they're easy. Two, they're grindy. Three, they're math optimization problems. All three of these sounds pretty good, but they sound like shit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze actively involves his community in the creative process, as seen when he agrees to let a viewer rewrite the cringeworthy 'Save State Yoshi' raps and immediately facilitates the collaboration over Discord.
context_findings.quote: We will need to have them remade. ... You wanna write new rhymes? I'm up for that. Send them my way.

biobak.summary: Kaze describes his workflow with Biobak, stating that he creates the initial models and Biobak then refines and improves them, confirming Biobak's role as a key artist and polisher.
biobak.quote: Usually after I'm done, we got Biobak looking over it and he makes them a lot better.

badub.summary: A viewer noted a melodic similarity in the Western level's music, composed by Badub, to the song 'I Will Survive,' an observation Kaze acknowledges.
badub.quote: Western level music pretty much has the exact same notes as the catchy part of it I will survive and I can't stop hearing it.

zeina.summary: Zeina, Kaze's wife and an animator on the team, was absent from the development session due to personal commitments (babysitting), giving a small glimpse into the team's work-life balance.
zeina.quote: Can you believe Zeina's on babysitting instead of making games with me right now? You can, damn. Such is life.

key_stories.title: The Invisible Mario Gun Solution
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to attach a gun to Mario's hand for a duel cutscene but faced engine limitations. He devised a clever and performant workaround by spawning a second, invisible Mario that perfectly mimics the player's animations, with only the gun attached to its hand being rendered.
key_stories.challenge: The game engine (a modified Mario 64) does not easily support attaching an external object like a gun to a character's hand bone in a performant way for a cutscene.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered and rejected capturing the hand's transformation matrix as too inefficient. He then developed the idea of an 'invisible Mario' rig. He worked through the technical steps in Blender and his codebase, overcoming model exporting and parenting issues to finally render the gun correctly in-game.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented the solution, which involved creating a second, invisible Mario character that copies the player's animations. The gun is attached to this invisible rig, allowing it to move perfectly with Mario at no extra performance cost during gameplay.
key_stories.key_quote: I can see the vision now of copying Mario's rig and attaching the gun to just his hand and then rendering an invisible Mario with only the hand visible where the hand is the gun.

key_stories.title: Planning for the Inevitable Takedown
key_stories.summary: Anticipating an inevitable copyright takedown of the game's trailer by Nintendo, Kaze planned a counter-strategy. He will prepare a second, 'copyright-free' version of the trailer to upload immediately, ensuring visibility is maintained and using the moment to promote his next project.
key_stories.challenge: Nintendo has a well-established history of issuing copyright takedowns against Kaze's fan projects and videos, posing a significant threat to the launch and visibility of the game.
key_stories.process: Drawing from his experience of having 70 videos taken down, Kaze anticipated that the game's trailer would be targeted. He planned a reactive strategy to minimize downtime and pivot the situation into a promotional opportunity for his future commercial work.
key_stories.outcome: A two-pronged trailer strategy has been decided on. He will release the main trailer, and if it's taken down, he will immediately upload a 'copyright-free' version. This secondary trailer will also serve as an advertisement for the Kickstarter of his next original game.
key_stories.key_quote: They will absolutely take it down and I will have to release a copyright free version that is gonna happen and you know it.

key_stories.title: Designing the Duel Countdown
key_stories.summary: Kaze iterated on the design for the duel's start, moving from a boring text countdown to a dynamic, cinematic cutscene. After finding the technical and design challenges of an animated HUD too great, he opted for a full cutscene with camera cuts to build tension.
key_stories.challenge: The initial idea for the Boshi duel countdown—a simple '3, 2, 1, Go!' on the HUD—felt uninspired and looked bad in practice.
key_stories.process: Kaze first tried a basic text display. Dissatisfied, he looked at Mario Party and Kirby for inspiration. After concluding that a purely HUD-based animated solution was too complex and 'painful' to program, he pivoted to using his existing cutscene tools to create a more dramatic and visually interesting introduction to the minigame.
key_stories.outcome: The duel now begins with a full cinematic cutscene, featuring dynamic camera shots focusing on Boshi and then Mario, before zooming out for the final showdown. This approach was deemed more engaging and easier to implement than a complex HUD animation.
key_stories.key_quote: I am not a fan of the 321... it does not look good. We need a better idea here.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned multiple times that he worked on two 'very, very cool' secret areas off-stream as part of a collaboration with another ROM hacker who requested secrecy.
questions: Who was the secret collaborator and what was the nature of your work together?
How did that collaborative process differ from working with your core team like Biobak or Zeina?
Now that the game is closer to release, can you reveal what those secret areas were?
What made them so 'cool' in your eyes?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated his release plan for the game's trailer includes bundling it with an advertisement for a Kickstarter for the original game he plans to make after finishing this project.
questions: What can you tell us about this next original game concept?
How has the process of deconstructing and rebuilding SM64 for this hack influenced your ideas for your own commercial game?
Why have you chosen Kickstarter as the funding model for your next step?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that he does initial model work, and then Biobak comes in and 'makes them a lot better.' The specifics of this handoff and improvement process are not detailed.
questions: Biobak, can you walk us through your process for improving one of Kaze's base models? What do you look for?
Kaze, can you recall a specific model that Biobak transformed, and explain the impact that had on the level or character?
How do you two handle creative differences on a model's final look?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions his wife Zeina, the animator, was busy with personal life during the stream. He jokes about her making games with him and making him pizza.
questions: Zeina, how do you and Kaze manage the line between your personal relationship and your professional collaboration on this huge project?
What are some of the animation challenges you've faced that are unique to the N64 engine?
How do you two resolve creative disagreements when they arise during development?

open_questions.context: Kaze found several 'cringe' raps for an anti-save-state feature and, upon chat's reaction, immediately accepted an offer from a viewer to rewrite them, exchanging Discord info live on stream.
questions: What was the outcome of that collaboration with the viewer on the 'Save State Yoshi' raps?
Did you use their rewritten lyrics in the final game?
How does this kind of spontaneous community contribution shape the final quirky details of the game?
